newsitem.title: UK: UK's FTSE shrugs of Dow weakness to close steady.
newsitem.headline: UK's FTSE shrugs of Dow weakness to close steady.

text.p: London's FTSE 100 share index fought off an early attack of Wall Street-inspired weakness to end little changed on Monday as investors tried to ignore fears of further losses across the Atlantic, dealers said.

Expectations of continued inflows of cash from private investors helped support the London market and cushion the impact of a faltering Wall Street. But with more testimony from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and key U.S. data looming, markets would remain on edge, dealers said.
The FTSE ended 1.2 points down at 4,307.1, its highest point of the day, after dropping as low as 4,287.3 in early trade.
"We've done remarkably well considering the state of Wall Street," one dealer said. "The Dow has come off more than 150 points in the last few days and we have been coping well."
Dealers said more money was expected this month from private investors, ahead of the April deadline for investing in Personal Equity Plans (PEPs), a tax-efficient method of share ownership.
"We've got another month in which all this PEP money will be coming in, so market-makers are trying not to get caught too short," one said. "That's helping us hold fairly steady."
Analysts said markets were awaiting the second half of Greenspan's Humphrey Hawkins testimony on Wednesday.

Last week Greenspan sent stock markets sharply lower with a warning that Wall Street's recent rise has "rasied questions of sustainability." The February U.S. employment report on Friday will also be a key focus for markets, analysts said.

"All the noise this week is about the results from companies here and some individual stocks will no doubt be affected, but we have the non-farms at the end of the week and that is what everybody is going to be looking at," said Philip Isherwood, UK strategist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.
Ex-dividends took 3.45 points off the FTSE on Monday morning and without their impact the index would have ended higher.
Advancing shares outnumbered declining shares by 52-45 but a few blue-chips took a tumble and weighed the index down.

Chief among them was National Westminster Bank Plc which dropped 28p to 730-1/2 after the announcement of a 50 million stg loss on options trading. The shares also went ex-dividend, compounding their weakness.
Most other major banking stocks were weaker too, with only Standard Chartered Plc and Royal Bank of Scotland going strongly against the trend.
Standard Chartered ended 25p firmer at 866-1/2 as positive sentiment after its results last week continued.
HSBC Holdings Plc, which reported a 23-percent rise in 1996 profits, finished down 30-1/2p at 15.515 stg. Chief executive John Bond predicted a challenging year ahead with increasing competition.
Business services group Hays Plc also suffered after releasing results, ending 15p lower at 536.
Vague bid talk continued to boost insurance shares, with Commercial Union Plc climbing 35-1/2p to 718-1/2.
Volume on SEAQ was an impressive 1.4 billion by 1635 GMT but dealers said this had been distorted by Yorkshire Water Plc and Southern Electric Plc's share buy-backs
The two companies contributed more than half the total volume on SEAQ and trade had in fact been relatively quiet, dealers said.
